+ Teen horror: Tick Tock (Goosebumps) — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
Teen Horror (Goosebumps style) Write a chapter where a middle school student discovers their new smart watch has the ability to rewind time, but doesn't realize that each use is aging them until they notice physical changes (like accelerating through puberty) and that people are treating them differently. They inadvertently cause a timeline shift with disastrous consequences -- and it can only be rectified (maybe?) by reversing the clock once more. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The box was plain, brown, and boring, with a shipping label from a company I’d never heard of: “Chrono-Tek.” I’d won it from a pop-up ad that promised a “revolutionary new wearable.” I was twelve, and “revolutionary” was my favorite word. Inside, nestled in cheap foam, was a smart watch. It was chunky and black, with a silicon strap that felt cold against my wrist. The screen flickered to life, displaying a simple digital clock in a blocky, retro font. Cool, I thought. A free watch. The first time it happened was in the cafeteria. I was carrying my tray, loaded with a wobbly rectangle of pizza, a carton of chocolate milk, and a scoop of green Jell-O that shimmied like a nervous ghost. Of course, that’s when Chad Mason, a walking collection of elbows and bad jokes, stuck his foot out. My world tilted. The tray flew. Pizza soared like a greasy frisbee. The milk carton spun, spraying a brown arc through the air. It was a slow-motion disaster. My hand, the one with the new watch, jerked instinctively. My thumb mashed against the single, unmarked button on the side of the watch. *BZZZZT.* The watch vibrated, a low, electric hum that seemed to go right up my arm and into my skull. The world lurched. The airborne pizza snapped back onto my tray. The arc of milk retracted into its carton. Chad’s foot slid back under the table. I was standing perfectly still, tray balanced, three feet away from where I’d tripped. I blinked. No one was staring. No one was laughing. It was as if it had never happened. I looked down at the watch. The time was the same, but for a split second, the numbers flickered, replaced by a different set: `99:59:59`. Then it was gone, back to the normal time. My heart hammered against my ribs. *Did that just… happen?* I spent the rest of the day testing it. Dropped my pencil in history class? *BZZZT*. Back in my hand. Said something dumb to Maya Jenkins, the girl with the cool, galaxy-print backpack? *BZZZT*. The words were back in my mouth, unsaid. Each time, the watch would buzz, the world would stutter backwards a few seconds, and the strange countdown would flicker on the screen, a little lower each time. `99:48:12`. `99:47:03`. It was the ultimate cheat code for life. The next morning, I looked in the mirror and frowned. There was a dark little speck on my upper lip. I rubbed it. It was coarse. A whisker? No way. I was a late bloomer, my friend Mark still called me “Squeaky.” I shrugged it off as a smudge of dirt and headed to school. In gym class, we were playing dodgeball, which was my personal version of hell. I was usually the first one out. But not today. A red rubber ball hurtled toward my face. *BZZZT*. I sidestepped it easily. Another one came for my legs. *BZZZT*. I jumped over it like a pro athlete. I was untouchable. A dodgeball ninja. Mark stared at me, his mouth hanging open. Even Mr. Davison, the gym teacher, grunted in approval. "Nice moves, Leo! You've had a growth spurt or something?" After class, I stood next to Mark. I’d always been a little shorter than him. But today… I was looking down at the top of his head. “Whoa,” he said, looking up at me. “Dude, when did you get so tall?” A cold knot formed in my stomach. Later that day, Maya stopped me in the hall. "Hey, Leo," she said, but she didn't meet my eyes like she usually did. She seemed… nervous. "Your voice sounds different." I cleared my throat. It came out as a low rumble. It wasn't a squeak anymore. It was deep. Too deep. That night, the panic truly set in. I stared at my reflection. My face was longer. My jaw was more defined. The single whisker had been joined by a few friends. My shoulders were broader, straining the seams of my favorite video game t-shirt. I looked like my older brother’s friend. I looked… thirteen. Maybe fourteen. I frantically pulled up the sleeve of my pajamas. The watch face was inert, showing the time. I tapped the screen, trying to find a menu, an instruction manual, anything. Nothing. Then, it flickered. The countdown. `41:16:50`. I’d used it maybe twenty times. Twenty little rewinds. And it had cost me… what? A year? Two years of my life? The blood drained from my face. The revolutionary new wearable wasn't a time machine. It was a life machine. And it was eating mine. The next day at school, I swore I wouldn't use it. I’d just have to live with my mistakes. But then came gym class. It was dodgeball again. The final showdown. Me and Maya against Chad and his goon squad. I was playing normally, getting by on my newfound height and reflexes. But Chad was a heat-seeking missile of pure malice. He wound up, aiming a ball straight at me. I could have dodged it. I was fast enough now. But in a moment of stupid, arrogant pride, I wanted to do more than dodge. I wanted to be a hero. I wanted to do one of those cool, slow-motion dodges from the movies and grab the ball right out of the air. The ball left his hand. I pressed the button. *BZZZZT.* The world rewound. The ball flew back into Chad’s hand. I set my feet, ready to be a legend. But something was different this time. A glitch in the timeline. As time snapped forward, Chad wasn't aiming at me anymore. His body had shifted a foot to the left during the rewind. His arm whipped forward. The red ball flew, not at me, but directly at Maya. She was looking the other way, talking to someone on the sidelines. She never saw it coming. *THWACK.* The sound was sickening. It hit her square in the side of the head. Her glasses flew off, skittering across the polished floor. Her eyes rolled back and she crumpled, not just falling, but collapsing. Her head hit the corner of the wooden bleachers with a hollow, awful crack. A girl screamed. The game stopped. Mr. Davison was yelling, running toward her. I stood frozen in the middle of the gym floor, a statue of horror. This was my fault. My stupid, selfish, arrogant fault. I looked from Maya’s still form to my own reflection in the scuffed varnish of the court. The face staring back at me wasn’t a kid’s face anymore. There were faint lines around my eyes, a shadow of exhaustion and age that hadn’t been there this morning. My gaze fell to my wrist. The watch felt like it weighed a thousand pounds. The screen flickered, not with the time, but with the countdown, burning into my vision like a brand. `08:42:15`. I could fix this. I could go back. Not just a few seconds. I’d have to rewind a whole minute. Erase the entire throw. But what would it cost me? Another year? Five? Would I come back a high schooler? An adult? And what would happen when that terrifying countdown finally hit zero? Mr. Davison was kneeling over Maya, shouting for someone to call 911. My hand hovered over the button, trembling. I had to choose. Maya’s life, or what was left of mine.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This Goosebumps-style teen horror story effectively captures the essence of the genre while delivering a compelling narrative about the consequences of manipulating time. The piece follows a middle school student who discovers a mysterious smart watch that can rewind time, only to realize that each use ages them prematurely. The story establishes its premise efficiently, introducing the watch as an innocuous prize that quickly reveals supernatural properties. The protagonist's initial excitement and casual use of the device feels authentic to a twelve-year-old's perspective. The gradual realization of the watch's true cost is well-paced, with physical changes that become increasingly alarming. The writing employs strong imagery throughout, particularly in the cafeteria scene where the food's trajectory is described in vivid detail. The author effectively uses sensory language to make the time-rewinding effect tangible: "The watch vibrated, a low, electric hum that seemed to go right up my arm and into my skull." These descriptive elements create a visceral reading experience. Character development is handled well within the constraints of the short format. The protagonist's transformation from an insecure "late bloomer" to someone making increasingly reckless decisions feels natural. Secondary characters like Mark, Maya, and Chad serve their narrative purposes without becoming mere plot devices. The story builds tension effectively, culminating in a genuine moral dilemma that raises the stakes dramatically. The final scene in the gym presents a true horror moment - not just supernatural horror, but the horror of causing serious harm to another person. The countdown timer on the watch creates a ticking clock element that adds urgency. There are a few minor weaknesses. The dialogue is limited but functional. Some of the physical aging descriptions could be more specific to create a stronger sense of body horror. The narrative also doesn't fully explore the social implications of the protagonist's rapid aging beyond a few brief interactions. The ending is appropriately dark and unresolved, leaving the reader with the protagonist's impossible choice - sacrifice years of their own life or let Maya suffer the consequences of their actions. This moral quandary elevates the piece beyond a simple cautionary tale about technology. Overall, this is a strong example of teen horror that balances supernatural elements with relatable adolescent concerns about physical changes, social status, and moral responsibility. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Noir romance: Carnival of Dangerous Intentions — Score: 84.3
Prompt:
Carnival of Dangerous Intentions Coney Island, New York, July 1937. She stopped just before reaching the shooting gallery set up along the boardwalk. It was near dusk, and the carnival lights were buzzing on. **His locks**. The words flashed through her mind, again, like an intruder. Such an old-fashioned turn of phrase that kept surfacing, and something else -- dangerously compelling -- quickly suppressed, lest she question why she had returned here at all. This place where she had promised to meet the stranger -- the young man with the obsidian curls and even darker eyes. She didn't even know his name. Write a scene in a larger story inspired by this prompt. The scene should capture an atmosphere that blends romantic allure with an undercurrent of subtle danger or moral ambiguity. Think 50 shades, but with a more restrained classic sensibility. The scene is all about establishing tension. Write for the feminine perspective. Include roughly 50% dialogue, 20% internal monologue, and 30% exposition and scene setting. The tone should have some edge to it. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Coney Island, New York, July 1937. She stopped just before reaching the shooting gallery set up along the boardwalk. It was near dusk, and the carnival lights were buzzing on, casting a jaundiced, festive glow on the peeling paint and the faces of the crowd. The air was a cacophony of glee and mechanics—the distant roar of the Cyclone, the tinny waltz of a carousel, the barker’s rhythmic drone. A thick, syrupy-sweet scent wafted from a nearby cart. Cotton candy. For a disorienting second, she was a little girl in a white lace dress, her father’s hand a warm, safe anchor in hers. The memory was a phantom, dissolving before she could grasp its edges, leaving only a hollow ache. **His locks**. The words flashed through her mind, again, like an intruder. Such an old-fashioned turn of phrase that kept surfacing, and something else -- dangerously compelling -- quickly suppressed, lest she question why she had returned here at all. This place where she had promised to meet the stranger -- the young man with the obsidian curls and even darker eyes. She didn't even know his name. *A fool’s errand,* she thought, the sensible part of her warring with the reckless pulse in her throat. *Turning up to meet a man you know nothing about. It’s the start of a cautionary tale they tell girls like you.* And yet, her feet remained planted on the worn planks of the boardwalk. “A woman of her word.” The voice was a low murmur, close to her ear, sending a shiver down her spine that had nothing to do with the encroaching sea breeze. “A rare and valuable thing.” She turned. He was leaning against the counter of the shooting gallery, one arm resting near a row of cork rifles. He hadn't been there a moment ago. He seemed to have materialized from the deepening shadows, a figure cut from twilight and smoke. He wore a dark suit, impeccably tailored, that stood in stark contrast to the casual attire of the summer crowd. His curls were just as she remembered, a chaotic frame for a face of unnerving stillness. His eyes held an amused, knowing glint. “You were so certain I would come,” she stated, her voice steadier than she felt. “I was,” he said, a faint smile playing on his lips. He pushed himself off the counter and gestured to the gallery. The targets were a row of tin ducks and spinning stars. “Precision is a virtue, is it not? In promises, in intentions… in aim.” *This was a game, and I did not know the rules. I only knew he was making them as he went.* Her internal monologue was a frantic whisper. She watched as he picked up a rifle, the movement fluid and economical. He didn't seem to aim so much as simply *will* the rifle into position. “What is it you want?” she asked, crossing her arms. It was a flimsy shield. He sighted down the barrel. “For you to enjoy the evening.” The sharp *crack* of the rifle punctuated his sentence. A tin duck at the far end of the gallery flipped over with a satisfying *plink*. He didn’t even look to see if he’d hit it. “Tell me, what does a girl like you dream of, wandering the edge of the world in a place like this?” “I’m not a girl,” she retorted, a little too sharply. “And I’m not wandering.” “No?” He set the rifle down and turned his full attention to her. It felt like being pinned in a spotlight. “You’re here with a purpose. My purpose.” He let the words hang in the air, a blatant claim of ownership that was both terrifying and thrilling. “I am a collector of beautiful, misplaced things. And you, my dear, look terribly misplaced.” Her heart hammered against her ribs. “And what do you do with the things you collect?” His smile widened, showing a flash of white teeth. “I give them a proper home. A place where they are appreciated. Valued.” He picked up another rifle, this one heavier, and offered it to her, butt first. “Your turn.” She hesitated, her hands clammy. “I don’t know how.” “Of course you do,” he said, his voice dropping to a confidential, almost hypnotic, timbre. “You just need to be reminded.” He stepped behind her, his presence a wall of heat at her back. He didn’t touch her, not yet, but she could feel the intention of it, a ghost of a caress. “Left hand here,” he murmured, his voice a low vibration against her ear. “Right hand on the trigger. Breathe out. Don’t think. Just… let go.” She did as she was told, her own will feeling like a distant shore. The rifle felt cold and heavy in her hands. She squinted, focusing on a spinning star, the world narrowing to that single, glittering point. The smell of gun oil and his clean, masculine scent filled her senses. She squeezed the trigger. The kick was a surprise, jolting through her shoulder. The cork went wide, thudding into the canvas backdrop. A failure. A hot flush of shame crept up her neck. “Almost,” he said, his voice laced with an indulgence that was worse than mockery. He took the rifle from her, his fingers brushing hers. The contact was electric, a jolt of lightning on a summer night. “Allow me.” He fired three times in quick succession. *Crack-plink. Crack-plink. Crack-plink.* Three stars spun wildly. The barker, a weary-looking man with a stained shirt, grunted and reached under the counter. “Winner. Pick a prize.” The man gestured to the wall of cheap, oversized dolls and garish stuffed animals. But the stranger shook his head. “Not those.” He spoke to the barker in a low tone, and a small bill was discreetly exchanged. The barker shrugged and pulled out a small, velvet-lined tray. On it lay a single object: a small, silver locket, tarnished with age, on a delicate chain. It was simple, elegant, and looked ancient. It belonged in an heirloom box, not a carnival stall. He picked it up and held it out to her. It lay in his palm, gleaming under the carnival lights. “I don’t understand,” she whispered. “You will.” His eyes held hers, dark and absolute. He didn’t place the locket in her hand. He waited for her to take it. A choice that felt like anything but. When her trembling fingers finally closed around the cool metal, he closed his own hand over hers for a brief, possessive moment. “Tomorrow,” he said. It was not a question. “The pier by the old parachute jump. Sundown.” He released her hand and, with a final, enigmatic smile, turned and melted back into the throng of people, leaving her standing there, the silver locket a cold, heavy weight in her palm. The scent of cotton candy was gone, replaced by the metallic tang of cordite and something else. The scent of a dangerous, unbreakable promise.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the requested atmosphere of romantic allure mixed with subtle danger. The author has created a tense encounter between a woman and a mysterious man with "obsidian curls" at Coney Island in 1937. The historical setting is well-established through sensory details like the "jaundiced, festive glow" of carnival lights and the "tinny waltz of a carousel." The character dynamics work well. The unnamed female protagonist displays appropriate wariness ("A fool's errand") while being drawn to the stranger despite her better judgment. The man is appropriately enigmatic and controlling, with dialogue that establishes him as both alluring and potentially dangerous ("I am a collector of beautiful, misplaced things"). The prose generally flows well, though occasionally veers into purple territory with phrases like "a figure cut from twilight and smoke" or "a wall of heat at her back." Some metaphors feel slightly overwrought, but they do contribute to the sensual, tense atmosphere requested in the prompt. The dialogue achieves the requested 50% balance and effectively reveals character while advancing the plot. The internal monologue provides insight into the protagonist's conflicted feelings, and the exposition establishes both setting and mood effectively. The shooting gallery scene works as an extended metaphor for power dynamics between the characters, with the man literally positioning the woman and teaching her to shoot. The locket exchange at the end creates a compelling hook for what would come next in a larger story. The piece successfully creates the requested tension and moral ambiguity. The protagonist knows she shouldn't be meeting this stranger, yet she's drawn to him. The man's possessiveness ("My purpose") and the protagonist's simultaneous fear and attraction create the edgy tone requested. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overwriting and a few instances where the internal monologue feels slightly artificial. The character's motivations could be more deeply explored - we understand she's drawn to him, but the specific psychological underpinnings remain somewhat vague. Overall, this is a strong response that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging scene that would fit well within a larger narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Surreal horror: Caribou Season at the Lodge — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
Caribou Season at the Lodge Genre: Surreal Horror JT knew something wasn't right from the moment they'd pulled up to the lodge. It looked exactly as it had every autumn of his life—the cedar shingles silvered with age, the porch sagging gently under weight of winters past—but the air felt thicker, somehow, as if the woods had leaned in closer, waiting. He thought maybe he was just tired. Maybe it was nothing more than the long drive north, cramped in the back of the truck beside his older brother Mike -- and a stack of rifles wrapped in oily canvas. Still, the feeling lingered. The first caribou they found that season hadn't bolted. It had just watched, ears flicking lazily, waiting for the shot. JT had felt a crawling in his gut watching it die, noticing how it fell with a quiet dignity—as though it had wanted nothing more. Nobody else seemed to find it odd, or at least they didn't say so. JT kept his mouth shut. Always safer that way. Then there was the moment in the clearing. JT had fallen behind, fumbling with bootlaces stiff from the cold, and by the time he'd caught up with his father and brother, they'd already stopped. JT slowed instinctively, ducking behind a tangle of brush, staring out into the open space where a massive buck stood utterly still, chest rising and falling in slow, deep breaths. The animal looked…wrong, somehow. Maybe it was the eyes—dark and flat, calm in a way that made JT's neck prickle. Or maybe it was something deeper, something in the way the buck stood close enough for his father to reach out and touch it. JT watched as his father raised a trembling hand toward the animal's muzzle. His father's face had a strange expression, eyes too bright, lips parted slightly, like he was on the verge of whispering something—a secret, maybe. The rifle hung uselessly at his side, forgotten. Mike had the same dazed look in his eyes. JT's breath stopped short, his mind suddenly shouting at him to look away, turn around, just run—but he couldn't move. And then, as suddenly as it had begun, it was over. The buck shivered, startled by something unseen, and disappeared into the brush without so much as a sound. The two of them looked around, confused, seemingly surprised to find themselves where they stood. JT stayed hidden, breathing shallowly, fear mingling with a confused sense of shame. His father had failed to take the shot. To even think about mentioning what he'd seen would have felt like betrayal—or something worse. JT waited until the others moved on before stepping out from cover. He stared into the empty clearing for a long, uneasy moment, wondering if anything had really happened at all, or if he was losing his grip. Maybe the woods were finally getting into his head. Writing Instructions: Continue with the next chapter of the story, maintaining a style reminiscent of Stephen King—grounded realism blended seamlessly with unsettling surrealism. The atmosphere should convey subtle dread, isolation, and psychological ambiguity. JT's perspective is crucial, yet he is an unreliable narrator, caught in uncertainty about what he's perceiving. Establish an undertone of creeping dread, establishing the isolation of JT's perspective, which he largely keeps to himself. Incorporate some dialogue. Build tension towards a payoff. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The walk back to the lodge was a silent, three-man funeral procession. The only sounds were the rhythmic crunch of their boots in the thin, early snow and the sigh of the wind through the skeletal branches of the birch trees. JT kept his eyes fixed on the back of his father’s red-and-black checkered jacket, watching the way his shoulders were set, not with the easy slump of a man tired from a long day’s hunt, but with a rigid, unnatural straightness. It was the posture of a man walking a high wire. Mike, for once, was quiet, his usual loud-mouthed swagger deflated, replaced by a sullen, confused energy that radiated off him in waves. JT tried to rearrange the events in the clearing into something that made sense. A buck gets spooked. A hunter hesitates. These were normal things, weren't they? But it wasn't the hesitation that had burrowed into him like a wood tick. It was the *communion*. The look on his father’s face, that rapturous, empty gaze, was the kind of thing you saw in old paintings of saints seeing visions. JT had never seen his father look at anything—not his mother, not his sons, not the biggest buck he’d ever bagged—with that kind of terrifying reverence. Back inside the lodge, the air was thick with the greasy smell of gun oil and wet wool. His father went straight to the stone fireplace and began laying a fire with jerky, fumbling movements, his hands still seeming to tremble slightly. Mike dropped his rifle onto the gun rack with a clatter that made JT jump. “I don’t get it, Dad,” Mike finally said, his voice too loud in the quiet room. He unlaced his boots, kicking them off with angry thuds. “That was the buck of a lifetime. A goddamn monster. You had him dead to rights. He was practically eating out of your hand.” His father didn’t turn from the fireplace. He struck a match, the flare illuminating his face, making his eyes look like dark hollows. “It wasn’t the one.” “Wasn’t the one? What the hell does that mean? He was standing ten feet away!” “I said,” his father’s voice was low and flat, a stone skipping on a frozen lake, “it wasn’t the one. Drop it, Michael.” The finality in his tone shut Mike up. He just shook his head and retreated to the kitchen, the clink of a whiskey bottle against a glass following him. JT sat on the edge of the worn leather couch, feeling like a ghost in his own family. The official story had been written: Dad had a moment of buck fever, a simple misjudgment. To contradict it, to say *I saw his face, I saw him reaching for it like a lover,* would be to shatter the fragile peace. So he said nothing. He just watched the fire catch, the flames licking at the dry kindling, casting long, dancing shadows that made the taxidermy heads on the walls seem to turn and watch them with their glassy, dead eyes. An hour later, the rumble of an old pickup truck broke the stillness. Headlights swept across the front windows, and JT saw the familiar, beat-to-hell Ford belonging to Beau, the local guide. Beau had been part of their annual trip for as long as JT could remember. He was a barrel-chested man with a laugh that could shake the shingles and a bottomless supply of off-color jokes and local lore. Usually, his arrival meant a fresh supply of beer and a long evening of storytelling. But the man who stepped onto the porch was a stranger. He didn’t knock, just pushed the door open a few inches and stood on the threshold, letting the cold air bleed into the room. He wasn't smiling. His face, usually ruddy and cheerful, was pale and drawn. He held a small propane canister in one hand. “Beau,” JT’s father said, turning from the fire. There was a flicker of something in his eyes—relief? Fear? “Come on in, man. We were just about to crack a bottle.” “Can’t,” Beau said. His eyes darted around the room, skipping over the rifles, the hunting gear, landing on each of them for a half-second before moving on. He wouldn't meet anyone's gaze. “Just dropping this off. Figured you might need it.” He set the canister down just inside the door. The silence stretched, thick and uncomfortable. “Everything alright?” Mike asked, leaning in the kitchen doorway. Beau finally looked at him, but his eyes were distant. “Weather’s turning. You folks should think about packing it in early this year.” “We just got here,” Mike scoffed. “Caribou are everywhere.” “That they are,” Beau said, and the words held no joy. He pulled his collar up around his neck, his gaze drifting to the window, to the darkening woods beyond. “All the same. You ought to be gone before the full moon.” JT’s father took a step forward. “The full moon’s not for another three nights. What’s the full moon got to do with anything, Beau?” Beau’s eyes finally met his, and for the first time, JT saw what was in them: a deep, profound fear. It was the same fear JT had felt in the clearing, the kind that was cold and ancient and had nothing to do with bears or getting lost. “It’s just… not a good time up here,” Beau said, his voice dropping to a near-whisper. “The woods… they get hungry. Things get thin.” He didn’t elaborate. He didn’t need to. He gave a curt nod, pulled the door shut, and was gone. The sound of his truck engine faded, leaving a silence that was heavier than before. “Crazy old coot,” Mike muttered, but there was no conviction in it. Later that night, JT lay in his bunk, listening to the lodge groaning under the weight of the wind. He couldn’t sleep. The image of the buck’s calm, dark eye was burned into his mind, and now Beau’s fearful face was right there beside it. He was sure he was the only one awake, until he heard a soft creak from the main room. Not the sound of the house settling, but a floorboard. He slipped out of his bed, his bare feet cold on the rough wood planking. The fire had died down to a bed of glowing orange embers, casting just enough light to see by. His father was standing at the front window, a silhouette against the snowy landscape outside. He was perfectly still, staring out into the night, towards the black wall of the forest. JT was about to call out to him, to ask if he was okay, when his father moved. He turned and walked, not back to his room, but to the front door. He moved with a slow, deliberate grace that was unnerving, like a sleepwalker. He unlatched the door without a sound and stepped out onto the porch. JT’s heart hammered against his ribs. He crept to the door, pushing it open just a crack, peering into the frigid night. The moon, not yet full but close to it, cast a pale, sickly light over the snow-dusted clearing. His father stood at the porch railing, his back to the lodge. In his hand, he held his hunting knife, its blade glinting in the moonlight. And then JT heard it. A quiet, rhythmic sound. *Scrape. Scrape. Scrape.* His father was carving into the thick cedar railing. Slowly, carefully, he was etching a shape into the wood. It was a spiral, elegant and complex, that branched and curved at the end, tapering to a sharp point. It was the unmistakable, undeniable shape of a caribou’s antler. He carved with the same rapt concentration JT had seen in the clearing, his head cocked as if listening to a secret whispered on the wind.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This continuation of the surreal horror story effectively maintains the established tone and atmosphere of the original piece. The writer has successfully captured the Stephen King-esque blend of grounded realism with unsettling surrealism, creating a palpable sense of dread that builds throughout. The prose is generally strong, with effective imagery that creates a vivid picture of the lodge and its surroundings. Descriptions like "the walk back to the lodge was a silent, three-man funeral procession" and "the flames licking at the dry kindling, casting long, dancing shadows that made the taxidermy heads on the walls seem to turn and watch them" establish both setting and mood efficiently. The character development is handled well, particularly JT's perspective as an unreliable narrator caught in uncertainty. His internal conflict about what he witnessed in the clearing and his reluctance to speak up feels authentic. The father's strange behavior is portrayed with subtlety, avoiding heavy-handed exposition while still conveying the wrongness of the situation. The dialogue serves the story effectively, particularly the tense exchange between Mike and the father about the missed shot, and later Beau's cryptic warnings. The characters' voices feel distinct and appropriate to their established personalities. The introduction of Beau as a harbinger of doom is a classic horror trope but is executed well, adding a layer of external validation to JT's concerns without fully explaining what's happening. The warning about the full moon and "things getting thin" introduces supernatural elements with appropriate restraint. The final scene with the father carving the antler shape into the railing delivers on the promised payoff, escalating the tension and leaving the reader with a disturbing image that suggests possession or influence by whatever entity is connected to the caribou. This scene effectively combines psychological horror with hints of the supernatural. There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly overwrought ("a stone skipping on a frozen lake"), but these are minimal and don't detract significantly from the overall quality. The pacing is well-managed, with a gradual build of tension that culminates in the final, unsettling scene. Overall, this is a strong continuation that honors the original piece while advancing the plot in intriguing ways. It successfully creates the requested atmosphere of dread and isolation while maintaining JT's crucial perspective as an unreliable narrator.
