+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 86.3
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The light flickered, a frantic pulse that matched the tremor in Kael’s left hand. A bank of salvaged solar panels on the roof, scoured from the skeletal remains of a suburban development, was feeding a stuttering stream of voltage into the lab. Each flicker made the shadows of the jury-rigged equipment leap and writhe like living things. Kael ignored it. He was used to the ghosts in his machine. His focus was narrowed to the glowing screen of a cracked datapad, its case held together with epoxy and hope. On it, a string of adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine scrolled past, a river of broken promises. This was Gentech Gold, the miracle wheat that had promised to feed the world. And it did, for one glorious, profitable generation. The corporate bastards who designed it had woven its doom into its very essence. A genetic time-bomb, a planned obsolescence that ensured farmers had to buy new seed every single year. When the corporations fell, their greatest weapon wasn't a bomb or a virus; it was the silence of their sterile fields. “Come on, you son of a bitch,” Kael muttered, his right hand steady as he guided a micropipette. The pipette itself was a relic, its calibration markings worn faint. He was trying to isolate a promoter sequence from a hardy, wild grass—a ‘weed’ from the before-times—and splice it into the Gentech Gold genome. If he could just bypass the self-destruct mechanism, they could have bread in The Warren that didn't taste like powdered despair. His PCR machine was a testament to post-collapse ingenuity. The thermal cycler’s heating block was cannibalized from a high-end coffee maker, its cooling system a fan pulled from a desktop computer tower, all of it governed by a simple microcontroller wired to a car battery that smoothed out the solar rig’s epileptic fits. It hummed, a low and constant prayer to the gods of thermodynamics. A tremor shot up his left arm, stronger this time. He paused, setting the pipette down and flexing his fingers. It was a side effect. One of many. The cocktail of retroviral agents he’d cooked up to fight the Blight was a roaring success, but the ride was rough. It had saved his lungs, but it left his nerves frayed and his chromosomes… creative. The upside was his vision. When the light flickered out completely for a second, the lab wasn't plunged into darkness for him. The world resolved into a landscape of heat signatures. The warm hum of the PCR machine glowed a gentle orange. The cooling metal of his tools were faint blue ghosts. Dust motes, invisible to a normal eye, danced in the air, tracing the thermal currents in infrared trails. The gift and the curse, all wrapped up in the same double helix. A sharp rap on the reinforced steel door cut through his concentration. No one came to the lab unannounced. He killed the datapad’s screen and palmed a scalpel from his workbench, its monomolecular edge still wickedly sharp. “State your name and business,” he called out, his voice flat. “Silas,” a smooth voice replied. “I have a contract. Sent by the Weavers.” Kael’s grip on the scalpel loosened slightly. The Weavers were a powerful faction from the glass towers of the old financial district, traders in information and influence. He slid the bolt and opened the door a crack. Silas was everything Kael was not. His clothes were clean, a dark grey synth-fabric that shed the dust of the Rustlands. His face was unmarred, his hands soft. He carried a polished chrome briefcase that looked painfully out of place. He smelled faintly of real soap. “The Weavers have a high opinion of your… talents,” Silas said, his eyes scanning the chaotic lab with a flicker of distaste. “I make plants grow,” Kael said, stepping aside to let him in. “It’s not magic.” “To some, it is,” Silas replied, setting the briefcase on the only clear patch of countertop. He opened it with a soft click. Inside, nestled in sterile foam, was a small, vacuum-sealed pouch of corn kernels and a data-slate. The corn was a deep, lustrous black. “Heirloom stock,” Kael breathed, recognizing it instantly. “True-seed. This is pre-collapse, maybe from a private vault.” It was the holy grail for biohackers like him—a genome untainted by corporate kill-switches. He could build a food supply for a generation on this. “It is,” Silas confirmed. “Our client has a rival settlement in the southern farmlands. They’ve managed to cultivate a significant crop of this true-seed maize. It gives them independence. It makes them a threat.” Kael felt a cold knot form in his stomach. He looked from the precious corn to Silas’s placid face. “What’s the job?” “The job,” Silas said, tapping the data-slate, “is to reverse your usual process. We don’t want you to fix a broken plant. We want you to break a healthy one.” The air went still, the only sound the hum of the fan on the PCR machine. “You want me to splice the Gentech obsolescence gene into this.” It wasn’t a question. “Precisely. This slate contains the marker sequences for the original Gentech terminator gene. You will engineer a virus, a phage, that can deliver this genetic package to their crop. It should be airborne and fast-acting. After one harvest, their fields will be sterile. They’ll be forced back to the negotiating table, dependent on our client for seed.” Kael stared at him. It was monstrous. It was the very evil he fought every single day, bottled and weaponized. He was being asked to put the shackles back on, to become the corporate demon he despised. “No,” Kael said, the word tasting like ash. “My work is for subsistence, not subjugation. Get out.” Silas didn’t flinch. He simply reached into his coat and produced a small, refrigerated vial. The liquid inside was clear. “The Weavers are aware of the outbreak in The Warren. The lung-rot affecting the children. Nasty bit of tailored bacteriology, left over from the corporate wars.” Kael’s blood ran cold. The cough was a wet, rattling thing that stole the breath from children in their sleep. He’d tried everything, but his own modified biology was no template for a cure. “This,” Silas said, holding up the vial, “is the specific bacteriophage needed to neutralize it. Pure, stable, and in sufficient quantity to treat your entire settlement. We trade you a cure for a curse.” Kael looked from the vial—salvation—to the black corn—damnation. His hand started to tremble again, not from the faulty nerve endings, but from the sheer weight of the choice. He thought of Maya, the council leader’s daughter, her small face pale, her breathing shallow. He thought of the future he was trying to build, one of freedom from the genetic tyrants of the past. Silas was offering him a chance to save the present by poisoning the future. With a ragged breath, Kael reached out his steady right hand, the one he used for his delicate work. He didn’t take the vial of medicine. He picked up the pouch of true-seed corn, its kernels feeling heavy and solid, like stones. “I’ll need a viable tissue sample from the target crop to ensure the phage’s vector is compatible,” Kael said, his voice a low rasp. “And I’ll need the payment up front.” A slow smile spread across Silas’s clean face. “Of course.” He pushed the vial across the counter. Kael picked it up. It was cold to the touch. In the lab’s flickering, uncertain light, he couldn’t tell if he was a saviour or a monster. Maybe in this broken world, they were the same thing.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter effectively creates a post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering has collapsed society through planned obsolescence in DNA. The author has crafted a compelling scenario featuring Kael, a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to create viable food crops. The worldbuilding is particularly strong, with detailed descriptions of jury-rigged equipment like the PCR machine "cannibalized from a high-end coffee maker" and cooling system "pulled from a desktop computer tower." The author effectively incorporates scientific terminology (PCR, adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine) that grounds the story in scientific reality while maintaining accessibility. The physical toll of genetic modifications is well-portrayed through Kael's trembling left hand and his enhanced infrared vision—showing both the costs and unexpected benefits of his self-experimentation. The author balances technical details with human elements, creating a world that feels lived-in and authentic. The black market contract forms the central conflict, presenting Kael with a moral dilemma that reveals his character and the harsh realities of this world. The choice between creating a weapon that perpetuates the very corporate evil he fights against versus obtaining medicine to save children in his settlement creates genuine tension. The prose is generally strong, with evocative descriptions and metaphors that enhance the atmosphere without becoming excessive. Occasional phrases like "powdered despair" and the PCR machine's "low and constant prayer to the gods of thermodynamics" add poetic touches that elevate the writing. The dialogue, though limited, effectively reveals character and advances the plot. The contrast between Kael and Silas is well-drawn through their appearance, manner, and speech patterns. The ending avoids an easy resolution, instead presenting a morally ambiguous choice that reflects the complexity of survival in this broken world. Kael's final thought—"In this broken world, he couldn't tell if he was a saviour or a monster. Maybe they were the same thing"—effectively captures the ethical compromises forced by desperate circumstances. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought, and a few instances where more showing rather than telling would strengthen the emotional impact. The character of Silas could be developed with more nuance beyond the clean/corporate stereotype. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully blends scientific concepts with human drama, creating a morally complex scenario in a well-realized post-apocalyptic setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Iteration 3 — Avg Score: 85.8
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The synthetic fibres of the collar chafed Arthur Neegan’s neck. He was a man accustomed to the worn, comfortable grit of a mining jumpsuit, its pockets heavy with tools and rock samples. This formal tunic, a severe grey garment of military precision, felt like a costume for a play he hadn't auditioned for. He sat stiffly in the plush acceleration couch, his calloused hands resting awkwardly on his knees, a stark contrast to the sleek, sterile white of the transfer vessel's cabin. Outside the reinforced plasteel port, Mars was a receding, rust-coloured marble, its familiar pockmarked face shrinking with every silent, efficient burn of the ship's drive. His small plot of land, Section 734-Delta of the Valles Marineris colonial grant, was down there. Until a week ago, it had been nothing more than a patch of ochre dust and rock, a place of quiet toil and modest ambition. Now, it was apparently the nexus of interstellar interest. The two guards who had collected him from his dome-home sat opposite, their faces impassive. They wore the same grey uniforms, but theirs were adorned with sidearms and the insignia of the Antares Diplomatic Corps—a stylized red giant star clutched in a silver gauntlet. A pretty name for what every spacer knew was a euphemism. The ADC handled matters that required a firm hand but a delicate public touch; they were the troubleshooters, the enforcers, the quiet arbiters for interests far beyond the fledgling Martian colonial authority. The vessel shuddered gently, a subtle shift in vibration indicating its final docking manoeuvres. There was no grand view of a planet or a moon, only the intricate, skeletal latticework of a massive space station, its position at the L4 Lagrange point a testament to its permanence and strategic importance. It was neutral ground, belonging to no single planet or corporation, and therefore the perfect place for a meeting one didn't want logged in any planetary records. One of the guards gestured. "This way, Mr. Neegan." Arthur followed, his mag-boots clanking with unfamiliar weight on the polished deck plates. The station's corridors were wide and silent, bathed in a cool, indirect light. It was the architecture of power, designed to awe and intimidate. They stopped before a heavy door that hissed open to reveal a circular chamber. The room was dominated by a large, round table of what looked like polished black obsidian. The far wall was a single, immense viewport, not of Mars, but of the colossal, striped face of Jupiter, its Great Red Spot a baleful, swirling eye. A woman stood by the window, her back to him, her silhouette framed against the gas giant's majesty. She turned as the door sealed behind him, leaving him alone with her. She was older than he’d expected, with sharp, intelligent eyes and silver hair swept back in a severe but elegant style. Her grey tunic was identical to his, but hers carried the rank of Administrator. "Mr. Neegan," she said, her voice calm and measured. "I am Administrator Valya. Thank you for coming. Please, have a seat." She gestured to a chair opposite her own. Arthur sat, the silence in the room amplifying the thudding of his own heart. "I wasn't aware I had a choice in the matter." A faint, wry smile touched her lips. "Force is a regrettably crude but effective tool for ensuring a conversation takes place. I trust your journey was not uncomfortable?" "It was… efficient," Arthur said, choosing his word carefully. He was an engineer. He appreciated efficiency. "Good." Valya sat down, her hands clasping on the table's surface. "Mr. Neegan, our modern galactic society is a complex mechanism. It functions, for the most part, on a delicate balance of economic and political pressures. Corporations like Trans-Solar Mining and Cydonia Resources, who currently dominate Mars, are a necessary part of that mechanism. They provide resources, employment, expansion. But they are, by their very nature, pathologically short-sighted." She paused, letting the statement hang in the air. "They see your claim, Section 734-Delta, and they see profit. They see a vein of Azra so pure and vast it could corner the market for a decade. They will offer you fortunes, Mr. Neegan. Enough to buy a private moon, if you were so inclined." Arthur remained silent. He had already received three such offers, each more astronomical than the last, each delivered with a thinly veiled threat. "What they do not see," Valya continued, her gaze unwavering, "is the consequence. Azra is not merely an exotic metal. It is a fundamental disruption. A substance that accelerates radioactive decay is, in effect, a key that unlocks near-limitless energy. In the hands of a responsible power, it fuels the starships that bind our civilization together. In the hands of anyone with a grievance and a fissionable isotope, it becomes the simplest and most terrifying weapon ever conceived." She leaned forward slightly. "The corporations on Mars will sell it. They will sell it to the highest bidder, without a thought for who that bidder is or what they intend to do with it. The Jovian Moons Separatists? The rogue factions in the Kuiper Belt? A bidding war for Azra will not be a gold rush, Mr. Neegan. It will be the overture to a war that could shatter the fragile peace we have enjoyed for two generations." Here it was. The big picture. His small patch of dirt, the focus of his life's work, was now a potential spark for interstellar conflict. He felt a cold knot tighten in his stomach. "Who are you?" Arthur asked, his voice low. "The Antares Diplomatic Corps is a convenient name. What power do you represent?" "A consortium," Valya said simply. "Of older, more established systems. We have seen this pattern before. A new technology, a new resource, emerges on the frontier, and the frontier powers, young and reckless, tear at each other for control of it. We are not interested in profiting from your discovery, Mr. Neegan. We are interested in containing it." "And how do you propose to do that?" "By making you an offer," she said, the finality in her tone making it clear this was the crux of their meeting. "We will not buy your Azra. We will buy your entire claim, under the legal authority of the Inter-System Colonial Charter, a treaty to which the Martian Authority is a signatory, whether the corporations like it or not. We will give you a price that is more than fair. But more than that, we will give you a position. Director of Martian Operations for the Antares Development Trust. You will oversee the extraction. You will ensure it is done safely, securely, and that the Azra goes only where it is sanctioned to go." She gestured to the star-dusted darkness beyond Jupiter. "You are a first-generation settler, an engineer. You understand Mars. You understand the science. We don't want to take your discovery from you. We want you to be its guardian. To help us ensure that your legacy is one of progress and stability, not one of fire and chaos." Arthur stared at her, his mind reeling. They weren't offering him money; they were offering him a purpose, a shield. And a cage. He would be their man on Mars, a figurehead with their power behind him, but a figurehead nonetheless. A pawn, perhaps, but a very important one. "And if I refuse?" he asked. "If I decide to take my chances with Trans-Solar?" Administrator Valya’s expression didn't change, but a profound sadness entered her eyes. "Then we will classify Azra as a Class-1 Proliferative Hazard under the same charter. We will blockade Mars. We will quarantine your claim. The corporations will be unable to get a single gram of it off-world. They will turn on you, Mr. Neegan, with a fury you cannot imagine. And we… will simply wait." She stood and walked back to the viewport. "The choice, as they say, is yours. You can be a king for a day on Mars, or you can play a part in the history of the galaxy. Consider it carefully." Jupiter watched him, vast, silent, and indifferent. And for the first time, Arthur Neegan truly understood the terrifying weight of the red dust under his feet.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures Asimov's style of science fiction, blending technical details with larger sociopolitical implications. The author has created a compelling scenario where Arthur Neegan, a mining engineer who discovered a valuable Azra vein, finds himself caught between powerful interests. The writing excels in world-building, establishing the political dynamics between corporations, colonial authorities, and the mysterious Antares Diplomatic Corps. The retrofuturistic elements are well-executed with details like "plasteel port," "mag-boots," and "dome-home" that give the piece an authentic classic sci-fi feel. The dialogue between Arthur and Administrator Valya forms the core of the chapter, and it's handled with skill. Valya's exposition about the dangers of Azra feels natural rather than forced, revealing the high stakes gradually. Her offer to Arthur presents a genuine moral dilemma that reflects Asimov's interest in ethical questions surrounding technology. The descriptive passages are strong, particularly the opening that establishes Arthur's discomfort in formal attire and the imposing setting of the space station. The imagery of Jupiter as a backdrop for the meeting adds visual grandeur while symbolically representing the vastness of the political forces at play. However, there are a few weaknesses. While the dialogue is generally strong, some of Arthur's responses could be more distinctive to establish his character more firmly. The piece also occasionally slips into telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining the nature of the Antares Diplomatic Corps. The prose sometimes becomes slightly purple, with metaphors like Jupiter's "Great Red Spot a baleful, swirling eye" that feel a bit overwrought for Asimov's typically cleaner style. Asimov was known for clarity and precision rather than poetic flourishes. Overall, this is a strong piece that captures the essence of classic sci-fi while telling an engaging story about a man caught in forces beyond his control. The author has successfully created a chapter that advances the plot while hinting at larger conflicts to come, true to the prompt's requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 84.1
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The darkroom smells of vinegar and possibility. It’s a scent I’ve come to associate with Elliot. Under the spectral red of the safelight, the world is stripped of its complexities, reduced to shadow and form. It’s a sacred space, a confessional booth where images, and secrets, emerge from the void. My brand, if you can call it that, is decisive. I wear bold prints, chop my own bangs with kitchen scissors, and have a history of dating men who are, for lack of a better word, simple. Easy to read, easy to lead. Then there’s Elliot. For months, I’ve watched him across the lecture hall, a quiet enigma in a sea of loud, posturing art students. He’s nineteen, all sharp angles and soft edges, dressed in a curated chaos of thrift-store nu-goth: oversized band tees, silver rings on slender fingers, combat boots that look like they’ve walked through a dozen different lifetimes. He doesn’t perform masculinity; he just… exists within it, quietly, thoughtfully. And it’s been driving me, a woman who always knows what she wants, completely insane. Now, we’re paired for our final project—a series on “transient identities”—and the universe is clearly having a laugh. We’re spending our nights in this crimson womb, our hands brushing as we pass tongs, our shoulders occasionally bumping in the tight quarters. “How’s that one looking?” I ask, my voice a low hum against the gentle sloshing of the developer tray. Elliot leans over the pan, his dark hair falling across his forehead. The red light catches the silver of his earring, the faint dusting of freckles across his nose. “The contrast is good,” he murmurs. “Maybe thirty more seconds in the stop bath.” I’m usually the one driving the conversation, filling the silence, directing the action. With Elliot, I find myself holding back, listening to the spaces between his words. Tonight, the silence feels different. Heavier. He’s been moving with a kind of careful fragility all evening, like he’s carrying something precious and breakable. Finally, as I’m clipping a dripping print to the line, he speaks, his voice barely disturbing the chemical-laced air. “Dani… can I ask you something… weird?” I turn, my heart giving a strange, unfamiliar lurch. My usual response would be a flippant, “Try me.” But the look on his face, a mixture of apprehension and desperate sincerity, stops me. I see the vulnerability he tries to hide behind his black nail polish and ripped denim. A fierce, protective instinct I didn't know I possessed rises in me. “Of course,” I say, my voice softer than I intended. He takes a breath, his gaze fixed on the ghostly image of a blurred face slowly sharpening on the paper. “You’re always so… sure of yourself. So comfortable in your own skin. Do you ever… feel like the person everyone sees isn’t the whole story?” My brain, usually a well-oiled machine of opinions and quick-fire responses, stalls. I think of the men I’ve dated, the clear lines I’ve always drawn. I like men. I like their solidity, their defined edges. I’d catalogued Elliot as ‘boy.’ A very specific, intriguing kind of boy, but the box was labelled. Now, he’s standing here, holding a pair of scissors to the tape on that very box. “Sometimes,” I admit, the word feeling inadequate. “Everyone wears a mask or two.” He gives a small, sad nod. “I feel like I’m wearing a whole costume,” he whispers. “And I’m getting really tired of the weight.” He finally looks at me, his eyes dark pools in the red glow. “I’ve been thinking a lot about… gender. And how I fit into it. Or… don’t.” There it is. The secret. The fragile thing he’s been carrying. It hangs in the air between us, shimmering and terrifying and beautiful. My usual impulse, the take-charge Dani, would be to offer solutions, to pepper him with questions, to fix it. *Have you talked to someone? What pronouns feel right? Let’s make a plan.* But that feels utterly wrong. Like trying to bolt scaffolding onto a butterfly. This isn’t my project to manage. A thrill, sharp and electric, shoots through me, tangled with my confusion. I’m witnessing something real and fragile and brave. It’s more compelling than any photograph we could ever create. But it also destabilises me. My attraction to him has been a quiet hum beneath the surface of our semester, an appreciation for his unique aesthetic and intellect. Now, the foundation of that attraction feels like it’s shifting. If he’s not the boy I thought he was, who is he? And who am I, being drawn to this unfolding person? “What does that feel like?” I ask, the question coming from a place of genuine curiosity, not a need to control. “For you.” Relief floods his face, so potent I can almost feel it wash over me. He hadn’t been looking for answers, just a witness. “Like I’m reading from the wrong script,” he says, his words coming a little easier now. “Some days, being a ‘he’ feels fine. Like a coat that fits okay. Other days… it feels like a straitjacket. I look at clothes, and I don’t just want to be a boy who looks good in a skirt. Sometimes I just want to… be.” He gestures vaguely, a beautiful, frustrated motion. “Not a boy. Not a girl. Just… me.” My phone buzzes silently in my pocket. It’s probably Leo, a guy I’ve been on a few dates with, the epitome of uncomplicated masculinity. He’ll be wanting to know if I’m free this weekend. The vibration is an anchor to my old world, my old self. I ignore it, pressing my thigh against the cool metal of the counter, grounding myself here, in the red light with Elliot. As he talks, I watch the image in the tray finally resolve. It’s a portrait of him, his face half-obscured by shadow, a study in ambiguity. It’s perfect. “It’s ready,” I say softly. We both reach for the tongs at the same time. Our fingers brush—his cool and slender, mine warm and capable. A jolt, undeniable and startling, passes between us. It’s not just the static of the dry room. It’s chemistry, raw and unexpected. He pulls his hand back quickly, but his eyes stay locked on mine. In the crimson glow, the four years and the world of difference between us dissolve, leaving just two people in a dark room, watching something new come into focus. He’s not a boy, not a problem to be solved. He is a revelation. And I, for the first time in a long time, have no idea what comes next. Who was I, if not the girl who knew exactly what she wanted? Elliot offers me a small, real smile, the first I’ve seen all night. It’s tentative and luminous. “Thanks, Dani,” he says. The project wasn’t about transient identities on paper. It was about this. Standing on the precipice of the unknown, together, with the whole uncharted territory stretching out before us. And all I could think was, *stay*.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her complex attraction to Elliot during their darkroom sessions. The piece effectively establishes Dani's assertive personality and her fascination with Elliot's unconventional masculinity, creating a compelling foundation for the narrative's central conflict. The writing excels in creating atmosphere. The darkroom setting is vividly rendered with sensory details ("smells of vinegar and possibility," "spectral red of the safelight") that establish an intimate, confessional space. This environment effectively supports the vulnerability of their exchange about gender identity. Character development is nuanced and believable. Dani's internal struggle between her usual take-charge attitude and her desire to give Elliot agency is well-portrayed. Her self-reflection about her attraction patterns and what Elliot's gender questioning means for her own identity feels authentic and thoughtful. Lines like "Who was I, if not the girl who knew exactly what she wanted?" effectively capture her emotional journey. The dialogue, though limited, serves the narrative well. Elliot's disclosure about gender identity ("Like I'm reading from the wrong script") feels natural rather than didactic. The conversation flows organically and reveals character rather than merely advancing plot. The prose generally strikes a good balance between descriptive richness and narrative momentum. Metaphors like the darkroom as "a crimson womb" and Elliot's gender as "a butterfly" that shouldn't have "scaffolding bolted onto it" are evocative without becoming purple. However, occasionally the writing becomes slightly overwrought, particularly in some of the more philosophical reflections. The narrative successfully avoids easy resolutions. The ending acknowledges the uncertainty of their situation while still providing emotional satisfaction. The chemistry between the characters develops naturally, and their connection feels earned rather than forced. One weakness is that some of Dani's internal monologues occasionally slip into telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining her usual dating patterns. Additionally, while the piece handles the theme of gender identity with sensitivity, Elliot's character could be developed further beyond his gender questioning to avoid making him seem defined solely by this aspect. Overall, this is a strong narrative that effectively captures the tender awkwardness of their interactions and the uncharted territory they find themselves in, both emotionally and relationally. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
### **Stolen Moments in Roma** **I. 09:14 – Piazza di Trevi** The Trevi Fountain was a glorious, roaring chaos, but Ben didn’t see it. He saw the neat, cross-referenced paragraphs of his guidebook, a pocket-sized sanctuary of order in a city determined to have none. He was trying to decipher a footnote about Bernini’s original intentions when the world dissolved into the shriek of tires on ancient cobblestones and a torrent of furious Italian. He stumbled back, his book flying from his hands, and met the blazing dark eyes of a woman astride a cherry-red Vespa. She was a kinetic sculpture of worn leather, wind-tousled hair escaping her helmet, and pure, undiluted indignation. “*Attento, idiota!*” she snapped, planting her boots firmly on the ground. The engine idled with an impatient growl, a wasp trapped in a jar. “Are your eyes just for decoration? *Mamma mia!*” Ben, whose entire being was a carefully curated collection of apologies, felt a system crash. “Oh, God, I am so sorry. Terribly sorry. *Mi scusi*… I wasn't looking…” She dismounted with a fluid, angry grace, snatching up his fallen guidebook. She thumbed through it with disdain. “*Rome in a Week*,” she read, her accent a sharp, musical staccato. “This is your problem. You are trying to read the menu while the meal is getting cold.” She tapped his chest with the book. “The city is *here*, *Professore*, not in the paper.” The honorific, dripping with sarcasm, should have stung. Instead, Ben found himself utterly mesmerized. The way her hands moved, the fire in her eyes, the sheer, unapologetic force of her. “I… yes. Right. I’m Ben.” A corner of her mouth twitched, the first crack in her fortress of fury. “Alessandra. And you are lucky my brakes are good.” She glanced from his flustered face to her scooter, then back again. An idea, wild and instantaneous, lit her expression. “*Allora*. Your book is useless. I will show you Rome.” “Oh, no, I couldn’t possibly impose…” “It is not an imposition,” she declared, her tone leaving no room for argument. “It is a rescue mission. Get on.” **II. 11:28 – Campo de’ Fiori Market** Ben had never been on the back of a scooter before. It was terrifying and exhilarating. Alessandra navigated the snarled Roman traffic not as a participant, but as a force of nature, a river carving its own path. They were a single, centrifugal entity, and Ben just held on, his scholarly world shrinking to the scent of her leather jacket and the dizzying blur of ochre-hued buildings. She pulled up at the edge of the Campo de’ Fiori market, a riot of colour and sound. “Espresso,” she commanded, dragging him to a packed counter. As they stood with their thimbles of potent coffee, she watched him. “So, *Professore* Ben. What great mystery do you study in our city?” “Roman graffiti, actually,” he said, feeling foolishly academic. “The *carmina epigraphica* of the plebeian class. What they wrote on walls…” Alessandra laughed, a throaty, genuine sound that turned heads. “Secrets on walls. I like this.” As they turned to leave, her hand darted out. In a movement so swift and fluid it was almost invisible, she plucked a single, perfect apricot from a vendor’s overflowing pyramid of fruit. It disappeared into her palm. Ben saw it. His mouth opened, a protest forming, but she was already walking away. A few steps later, she turned, broke the apricot in half with her thumb, and offered him a piece. Her eyes dared him. He hesitated for a fraction of a second before taking it. The fruit was warm from the sun, impossibly sweet. A shared, stolen treasure. He was an accomplice. A quiet, thrilling rebellion sparked in his chest. **III. 14:03 – The Gianicolo Hill** “You English,” she said, gazing out over the sprawling panorama of Rome from the top of the Gianicolo Hill, “you live your lives in straight lines. Schedules. Queues. Apologies.” “There’s a certain comfort in order,” Ben offered, his voice softer now, less flustered. “Order is boring,” she countered, leaning against the stone balustrade. She was toying with a small, silver object in her hand, rolling it between her fingers. Ben squinted. It was his pen, the one he’d had clipped to his shirt pocket. He hadn’t even felt her take it. “Rome… Rome is beautiful because it is a mess. It has history and blood and secrets piled on top of each other. You cannot put that in a guidebook.” She looked at him, her expression a playful challenge. “You want to feel it? Yell something.” “What?” “Yell. Something stupid. Something you would never say in your tidy life in… where are you from? Cambridge?” “Oxford,” he corrected, blushing. “Even worse. Yell, *Professore*.” He looked down at the domes and rooftops. He thought of his quiet office, his neat stacks of books, his predictable future. He took a breath, and to his own profound astonishment, he shouted, “I left the kettle on!” Alessandra stared at him for a beat, then threw her head back and roared with laughter. It was the most beautiful sound he had ever heard. He felt his own laugh bubble up, light and unburdened. For a moment, standing on that hill, he wasn't a British academic. He was just a man laughing with a beautiful, chaotic woman who had stolen his pen. **IV. 16:47 – Under a Gelateria Awning** The sky broke without warning. One moment, the sun was beating down on the cobblestones of a quiet Trastevere side street; the next, a torrential downpour sent them scrambling for the nearest shelter—the narrow green-and-white striped awning of a closed gelateria. The world shrank to the space of a few square feet. Rain hammered down, creating a curtain of water around them, muffling the city. The air grew thick with the smell of wet stone and ozone. Ben could see the bright, artificial colours of the gelato tubs through the glass: acid-green pistachio, deep magenta *amarena*, sunshine yellow lemon. He was intensely aware of her proximity, the warmth radiating from her arm, inches from his own. The playful, mischievous energy had softened, replaced by a quiet intensity. Her teasing gaze was gone, and she was just looking at him, her hair plastered to her temples, raindrops clinging to her eyelashes. The ambiguity that had simmered all day—was she mocking him? Playing with him?—suddenly felt like something else entirely. Something heavier. “So,” Ben said, his voice barely a whisper above the storm. “What happens now?” Alessandra didn't answer immediately. Her eyes flickered to the gelato shop’s counter. With a furtive glance, she reached under the slightly-raised security shutter, her fingers closing around two sugar-dusted waffle cone fragments left on the display. She pulled her hand back, a conspirator’s grin returning. She offered one to him. A tiny, perfect, stolen moment. As his fingers brushed against hers to take it, the rain began to slow. The spell was breaking. “Now,” she said, her voice low and enigmatic, “the tour is over.” She took his guidebook from her jacket pocket. Ben reached for it, but she held it back. She uncapped his silver pen, scribbled something on the inside cover, and then, instead of returning it, she tucked the book securely back into her own jacket. “Hey, that’s…” “You don’t need it anymore,” she said, her eyes locking with his. The dare was back, but it held a new promise. “Meet me tomorrow. Piazza Navona. The fountain with the big man wrestling the sea monster. Noon.” She gave him a final, lingering look, a complex mix of mischief and something he couldn't decipher. Then, before he could respond, she darted back out into the glistening street, swung a leg over her Vespa, and with a final, audacious wink, revved the engine and disappeared around the corner. Ben stood under the awning, soaked, disoriented, and without his book or his pen. The stolen piece of waffle cone tasted of sugar and rain and the exhilarating promise of noon. He was utterly, hopelessly smitten.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of a contemporary romance set in Rome, following the prompt's requirements for a clash of cultures between Alessandra, the fiery Italian motorcycle courier, and Ben, the polite British academic. The narrative is structured as a series of interconnected scenes spanning a single day, as requested. The writing excels in establishing vivid imagery of Rome and creating distinct character voices. Alessandra's impulsive, energetic nature contrasts effectively with Ben's reserved, scholarly demeanor. The author skillfully incorporates Alessandra's kleptomania through subtle acts throughout the day (stealing an apricot, Ben's pen, and waffle cone fragments), rather than explicitly stating it. The dialogue is particularly strong, with Alessandra's sharp, accented English and Italian phrases creating an authentic voice. Ben's flustered responses and gradual relaxation show character development within a short span. Their exchanges reveal their personalities naturally without exposition. The narrative effectively builds tension and chemistry between the characters. The progression from their initial clash at the Trevi Fountain to the intimate moment under the gelateria awning feels organic. Ben's transformation from a guidebook-dependent tourist to someone willing to shout nonsense from a hilltop demonstrates character growth that, while quick, is made believable by Alessandra's magnetic personality. The prose balances descriptive richness with forward momentum. Sensory details like "the scent of her leather jacket," the taste of the "impossibly sweet" stolen apricot, and the "smell of wet stone and ozone" during the rainstorm create immersion without becoming excessive. The ending successfully creates anticipation for their next meeting while maintaining the ambiguity of Alessandra's feelings, as specified in the prompt. The final image of Ben standing alone with the stolen waffle cone, "utterly, hopelessly smitten," effectively captures the emotional impact of their day together. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought ("a kinetic sculpture of worn leather") and a few instances where character development happens somewhat rapidly given the timeframe. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise well-crafted piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 82.8
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The station’s artificial gravity gives a little sigh, and the amber liquid in Kael’s glass shivers, its surface a trembling jewel under the dim bar lights. He doesn’t notice. He’s too deep into his story about wrestling a rogue mining drone with a spanner and a string of inventive curses. “And I tell ya, Nets, the little scrapper had more fight in it than a Glib-worm in a salt bath,” he says, his voice a low rumble that vibrates through the scuffed durasteel of the bar. I nod, polishing a glass until it squeaks. “Sounds like you showed it who’s boss, Kael.” “Damn right I did.” He drains his glass in one go. The gravity shivers again, a little stronger this time, and a few drops of ale slosh onto the bar. I wipe them away before they can get sticky. It’s a constant, gentle rhythm here at The Last Outpost: the hum of the life support, the clink of glasses, the wobble of the gravity plates, and the stories. Always the stories. This place is my equilibrium. A perfect balance of quiet and chaos, far enough from everything that matters to anyone who used to matter to me. My past is a sealed container I’ve jettisoned into a dead orbit. Most days, I almost believe it won’t come spiraling back. “Another?” I ask Kael. Before he can answer, Lyra, a merchant with eyes as sharp as the crystal shards she trades, slides onto the stool next to him. “Don’t encourage him, Nets. He’ll be telling us the one about the sentient asteroid again.” “It had a face!” Kael insists, pointing a grizzled finger at her. “Looked just like my mother-in-law.” “Your mother-in-law is a lovely woman, Kael. She doesn’t deserve that,” Lyra retorts, her lips twitching into a smile. “Just a synth-ale for me, Nets. Long haul from the Kepler Belt.” “Rough trip?” I ask, pulling the tap. “The usual. Pirates are getting bolder, but the Guild patrol is getting lazier. It’s a delicate ecosystem.” She accepts the foaming mug, her gaze sweeping the room. It’s a slow night. A few prospectors are huddled in a booth, their conversation a low murmur. A pair of off-duty cargo haulers are losing credits to a glitchy card game in the corner. Normal. That’s when the door hisses open, letting in a gust of recycled air that smells faintly of ozone and engine coolant. The newcomer pauses for a moment, silhouetted against the corridor lights, before shuffling towards the bar. He’s a Xylotian, I think, from the cluster of thin, prehensile tentacles that hang from his scalp like dreadlocks. They’re usually a deep, glossy black, but his are frayed at the tips and dusted with something that looks like asteroid grit. His clothes are good quality but rumpled, as if he’s been sleeping in them for a week. He slumps onto a stool at the far end of the bar, away from Lyra and Kael, keeping his shoulders hunched. His eyes, large and silver, dart around the room before settling on me. “Vega whisky, neat,” he says, his voice a dry whisper. “Better make that a double.” I give a small, professional nod. No questions. The Last Outpost is built on a foundation of ‘no questions asked.’ I grab a heavy-bottomed tumbler and the distinctive hexagonal bottle of Vega whisky. As I pour, the gravity dips again, and the golden liquid sloshes precariously close to the rim. The stranger’s hand, resting on the bar, trembles in time with it. I slide the glass over. “Hundred credits.” He fumbles in a pocket, pulling out a worn credit chip and sliding it across the bar without meeting my eyes. I process the payment. He wraps both hands around the glass, his tentacles twitching slightly, and takes a long, shuddering swallow. “Rough day?” I ask, my voice neutral. It’s the standard bartender’s opening. Sometimes they want to talk. Sometimes they just want the silence. He gives a short, bitter laugh that’s more of a cough. “You could say that. You could also say the star is hot or the void is cold.” He takes another sip, his silver eyes scanning the entrance again. He’s waiting for something. Or someone. “This place… it’s the last stop before the Black Expanse, right?” he asks. “We’re the last place with a working airlock and a decent drink, if that’s what you mean,” I reply, leaning against the back counter. “Not much beyond us but dust and dreams.” “Good. Dust is good.” He drains half the glass. “I need a ship. A fast one. One that doesn’t keep detailed logs.” Lyra, ever the opportunist, overhears from two stools down. “Fast ships that don’t keep logs cost a premium, friend. What are you hauling? Or what’s hauling after you?” The stranger’s head snaps toward her, his expression turning sharp with fear. “I’m not your friend, and that’s none of your business.” “Easy there,” I say, stepping in smoothly. “Lyra’s just got a nose for business. It’s a chronic condition.” Lyra gives a placid shrug, but her eyes are calculating. Trouble is a commodity like any other, and she’s always looking to invest. The stranger turns back to me, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. “Look, I just need a name. Someone who can get me out of here. No questions.” “People who ask no questions are usually the ones you should be most worried about,” I say quietly. It’s a lesson I learned the hard way. “What kind of trouble are we talking about? Local syndicate? Unhappy spouse?” He shakes his head, one of his tentacles coiling nervously around his finger. “Worse. The Chroma Guild.” My blood runs cold. Not a syndicate. A corporation. One of the big ones, with private armies and a reach that extends a lot further than the Andromeda outer rim. They don’t just handle disputes; they erase them. My past may be in a dead orbit, but the Chroma Guild owns half the satellites in this quadrant. “The Guild doesn’t operate out this far,” I lie, my voice steady. “They have no interests here.” “They do now,” he mutters, his gaze fixed on the bottom of his empty glass. He pushes it forward. “Another.” As I reach for the bottle, the bar door hisses open again. Two figures step inside. They aren’t miners or merchants. They’re dressed in sleek, grey fatigues with no insignia, but they don’t need any. It’s in the way they stand, the way their eyes methodically sweep the room, cataloging every face, every exit. Their movements are economical, predatory. One of them, a human with a chrome-sheen data port where his left eye should be, meets my gaze for a fraction of a second. There’s no emotion there. Just assessment. Every muscle in my body tenses. My carefully constructed equilibrium shatters. The Xylotian at my bar goes utterly still. The tentacle wrapped around his finger tightens, and the blood drains from his face, leaving his skin a pasty grey. “Nets,” he whispers, his voice barely audible, his silver eyes wide with pure terror. “My name is Zorin. Don’t let them take me.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a cozy sci-fi atmosphere while establishing clear conflict. The author has crafted a first-person, present-tense narrative as requested, with the protagonist Nets bartending at The Last Outpost. The writing effectively establishes the setting as a hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt, and introduces the frazzled stranger with "tentacled dreads" who orders a Vega whisky. The dialogue comprises roughly 60% of the text as requested, and the author has created a conflict involving the Chroma Guild that remains unresolved at the chapter's end. The word count appears to be approximately 1,000 words as specified. The strongest elements of this piece are the atmospheric details and world-building. The writer creates a lived-in universe with references to specific locations (Kepler Belt, Black Expanse), species (Xylotian), and organizations (Chroma Guild) without overwhelming exposition. Small details like the "artificial gravity gives a little sigh" and drinks that "shiver" create a tangible environment. The dialogue flows naturally between characters, revealing personality and advancing the plot simultaneously. Each character has a distinct voice - Kael's boisterous storytelling, Lyra's sharp business sense, and Zorin's fearful desperation. However, there are some weaknesses. While the protagonist Nets has an intriguing backstory hinted at ("My past is a sealed container I've jettisoned into a dead orbit"), we don't get much depth to her character beyond her bartender role. The narrative relies somewhat on familiar tropes - the mysterious stranger in trouble, corporate villains, the bartender with a hidden past. While these work effectively in the genre, they don't break new ground. The ending creates genuine tension with the arrival of the Guild agents, but the final line ("Don't let them take me") feels slightly melodramatic compared to the more nuanced tone established earlier. Overall, this is a solid piece of cozy sci-fi that successfully establishes an interesting setting, introduces characters with potential for development, and creates a conflict that leaves the reader wanting to know what happens next. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 80.5
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The air in New Orleans is thick. Not like the humid, green-smelling thickness of a Tennessee summer, but something else. It’s like trying to breathe through wet velvet, and it smells of sugar, stale beer, and the muddy ghost of the Mississippi River. The truck driver who’d given me a ride from just outside Biloxi had grunted, “End of the line, kid,” and shoved my backpack at me before peeling out, leaving me on a corner where the wrought-iron balconies looked like they were dripping black lace onto the sidewalk. My name is Taylor. Or, it is now. Back home, it was something else, something that fit me as well as my mom’s church dresses, which is to say, not at all. *You’re a girl. You will act like one.* Dad’s voice, a low rumble of thunder that promised a storm. *We just don’t understand, honey. This isn’t you.* Mom’s voice, a high, pleading whine that was somehow worse. I shake my head, trying to dislodge them. It doesn’t work. They’re squatters in my brain. The last 48 hours had been a highlight reel of their greatest hits of disappointment. The "concerning behavioural patterns" Mr. Henderson, the smug counsellor, used to talk about were things like skipping class to smoke stolen cigarettes by the creek, or painting a mural on the water tower that was, in hindsight, probably a little obscene. Invented drama, born of a boredom so profound it felt like a physical weight. This, though. This wasn't invented. This was the truest thing I’d ever done, and it had detonated my life. So I ran. A duffel bag with two changes of clothes, the eighty-four dollars I’d saved from my miserable diner job, and my phone. I pull it out. 12%. Seven missed calls from Mom. One from Dad. I shove it back in my pocket, the vibration of a new text buzzing against my thigh. Probably Mom again. *Please just come home. We can talk.* Talk meant them talking and me listening. No thanks. My stomach growls, a hollow, aching sound that gets lost in the clang of a streetcar and the mournful wail of a saxophone from down the block. I need a plan. Step one of running away: survive. Step two: figure out the rest later. Right now, survival smells a lot like the fried dough and powdered sugar wafting from a cafe across the street. I look at the cafe, then at the crumpled bills in my hand. Eighty-four dollars has to last. How long? I have no idea. A week? A month? A lifetime? The thought is a cold fist clenching in my gut. “You look like a baby bird that fell out of the nest.” The voice is gravelly, amused. I flinch and turn. Leaning against a lamppost is a person who looks about my age, maybe a year or two older. They have choppy, faded-pink hair, a silver ring in their septum, and eyes that look like they’ve seen more than their fair share of… well, everything. Their clothes are a patchwork of worn denim and band t-shirts, held together by safety pins and defiance. “I’m not a baby bird,” I say, my voice coming out harsher than I intended. They just smirk, pushing off the lamppost. “Sure you’re not. Fresh off the bus, though, am I right? Got that deer-in-the-headlights look. Name’s Jax.” “Taylor,” I mutter, clutching the strap of my backpack. Rule one of being on your own: don’t trust anyone. Especially not people who look like they could pick your pocket and you wouldn’t even notice. “Taylor.” Jax tests the name out. “So, Taylor-who’s-not-a-baby-bird, you hungry? You’re staring at Café Du Monde like it’s the promised land.” My stomach betrays me with another loud rumble. Jax laughs, a short, sharp sound. “Thought so. C’mon.” They start walking, and for some reason, I follow. What’s the alternative? Standing on this corner until I fossilize? “I don’t have a lot of money,” I say, catching up to them. “Who said anything about money?” Jax grins, and it’s a flash of mischief that feels both dangerous and incredibly familiar. It’s the same look I used to get right before I did something stupid. We stop a little ways from the cafe’s bustling, open-air patio. “Okay, here’s the deal,” Jax says, dropping their voice. “The waiters are crazy busy. I’m gonna go cause a little scene. Knock over a chair, argue about an imaginary bill, whatever. When they’re distracted, you walk past that table on the end—see it?—and grab the bag of beignets the tourists left. They barely touched ‘em. Then you walk, don't run, around the block and meet me by the river. Got it?” My heart starts hammering. This is it. This is the line. Back home, this would be a thrill, a story to tell. Here, it’s… food. My internal monologue is a frantic debate. *This is stealing. You could get caught. The cops…* But the other side argues back, louder. *You’re starving. Your parents threw you out. The world isn’t playing fair, why should you?* I see the untouched white paper bag on the table. It’s practically glowing. I nod, my throat too dry to speak. Jax gives me a sharp, assessing look. “You sure? You look like you’re about to puke.” “I’m sure,” I manage. “Alright. Count to thirty.” And then they’re gone, melting into the crowd. I count, my hands shaking. At twenty-five, I hear a clatter and a raised voice. “What do you mean I have to pay for this? It’s mostly sugar and air!” It’s my cue. I walk. My legs feel like they’re filled with concrete. Past the table. My hand darts out, snags the bag. It’s still warm. I don’t run. I walk, just like they said, my heart trying to beat its way out of my ribs. I find Jax leaning on the railing overlooking the river, nonchalantly tossing a bottle cap in the air. They grin when they see me. “Success?” I hold up the bag. We find a bench, and I tear it open. The beignets are a miracle, warm and soft and buried in a mountain of powdered sugar. I take a bite and a cloud of white dust explodes over my face and jacket. I don’t even care. It’s the best thing I’ve ever tasted. We eat in silence for a minute. “So,” Jax says, wiping sugar from their chin. “What’s your story, Taylor? Everyone’s running from something.” I hesitate. The truth feels like a raw, open wound. Saying it out loud to my parents was a disaster. Why would a stranger be any different? “Family stuff,” I say vaguely. Jax nods, not pushing. “Fair enough. Pronouns?” The question is so casual, so direct, it throws me. “Uh… they/them.” I brace myself for the flicker of confusion, the slight recoil. I don’t get one. “Cool,” Jax says, popping the last piece of beignet into their mouth. “Jax. They/them too.” And just like that, a little bit of the tension I’ve been holding in my shoulders for my entire life, but especially for the last two days, just… releases. It’s a quiet, internal sigh of relief. For the first time since I left, I feel like I can actually breathe this thick, foreign air. “So where are you crashing tonight?” Jax asks. The question brings the cold fist of reality back to my gut. “Haven’t figured that out yet.” Jax studies me for a long moment, their gaze unreadable. I pull out my phone again. 8%. The screen lights up with another message from Mom. My thumb hovers over it. “You can’t stay on the streets,” Jax says, their voice serious now. “Not your first night. It’s not safe.” “I’ll find a shelter or something,” I lie. “They’re all full,” Jax says, like it’s a fact they know from personal experience. “Look. I know a spot. It’s not the Ritz, but it’s dry. And safe. Mostly.” Trust. That word again. My mind screams at me not to be an idiot. This is how kids disappear. But my gut, the same gut that told me to run, is telling me something different. It’s telling me that this person, this stranger who shares my pronouns and stole pastries for me, might be the only anchor I have in this entire, swirling city. For the first time in forty-eight hours, the silence in my head wasn't screaming. It was just quiet. Waiting for my answer. “Alright,” I say, my voice barely a whisper. “Lead the way.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a transgender teen runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The writing establishes Taylor's character immediately through their internal monologue, revealing their backstory organically while maintaining a consistent first-person perspective as requested. The prose is strongest in its sensory descriptions of New Orleans, with evocative lines like "trying to breathe through wet velvet" and the city smelling of "sugar, stale beer, and the muddy ghost of the Mississippi River." These details ground the reader in the setting while reflecting Taylor's emotional state. The character of Jax serves as an effective foil and potential ally, introducing both danger and possibility. Their introduction creates tension while advancing the plot naturally. The petty theft scene effectively builds suspense and reveals character through action rather than exposition. The dialogue between Taylor and Jax feels authentic to teenagers in their situation - guarded but seeking connection. The casual way Jax asks about pronouns creates a powerful moment of recognition for Taylor, though this emotional beat could have been explored with more depth. Where the writing falters is in some overreliance on familiar metaphors ("cold fist clenching in my gut") and occasionally telling emotional states rather than fully embodying them through action and sensory detail. The internal conflict about stealing the beignets is somewhat simplistically rendered. The piece maintains consistent voice throughout, capturing Taylor's mix of defiance, fear, and vulnerability. The ending effectively sets up tension for what might come next without resolving too much. Overall, the writing successfully establishes character, setting, and conflict while maintaining the requested perspective and emotional complexity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
